Aeropress]
The aero-press, designed by the inventor of the Aerobie Ring (a flying ring), is a great light-weight travel companion loved by many in the coffee world. It can be used with a paper or metal filter and combines emersion and pressure brewing resulting in a full-bodied and fragrent cup.
Load filter over cover and screw onto bottom-half of brewer, set on top of a cup or carafe.
Wet filter and warm brewer by pouring hot water into lower half.
Grind coffee on slightly finer grind than paper filter, dump hot water from carafe, positioning back under the brewer, and dump grounds into tube.>
Pour INT UNITS of water into brewer, filling to the top.
Using a spoon, stir grounds at bottom of brewer gently.
Slide top half of brewer in bottom half, initially in an angle, and then straighten out into a vertical position.
At 1:00 remove entire setup off of scale, and gently press using just body weight. Complete press should finish at 1:30.
Stir coffee in carafe and serve.
Frenchpress]
The french press is perhaps the easiest brew-method to achieve a good tasting cup of coffee. The method a full-emersion technique and filters through a metal screen. The method has the biggest body/mouth feel due to the high amount of sediment that passes through the screen; this also results in muted acidity and nuanced flavors.
Pour a small amount of hot water into the vessel to preheat.
Grind the coffee on a course/french press setting.
Pour out pre-heat water and dump in grounds.
Start timer and pour in INT grams of water.
With a spoon, stir wet grounds to fully expose to water.
Let sit for 30 seconds.
Last pour to finish at INT UNITS.
At 4:00 minutes, gently press plunger to completion.
Pour out all of coffee into cup or carraff to serve, leaving none left in the french press. Coffee left in the french press will continue to brew and could over extract.
Hario V-60]
The hario V-60 is capable of so much, but it is easy to mess up. When done right, the body is smooth and those bright acidic notes really shine through the cup. The V-60 is a pour-over drip with ridges on the walls of the vessel which allow for greater flow. Detail to your method of pouring is required and a gooseneck kettle is recommended.
Place vessel either on top of coffee cup or on stand with cup/carafe below.
Crease the paper filter along the ridged edge, place the filter in the brewer and completely wet with hot water.
Grind the coffee on a V-60/paper filter setting, dump grounds in brewer, dump out hot water from cup/carafe.
Start timer and make initial pour of INT UNITS, take a spoon and stir the grounds to ensure that all grinds are wet. Let bloom.
At 45 seconds, slowly pour bringing the total amount of water to INT UNITS. When pouring, make small concentric circles in the center, ensuring to not touch the sides of the brewer. Pour should be 15 seconds finishing at 1:00.
At 1:30 begin third pour, bringing the total amount of water to INT UNITS, finishing at 1:45.
At 2:00 begin the last pour, bringing the toal amount of water to INT UNITS, finishing at 2:15.
Coffee should finish dripping around 2:30-3:15, remove brewer and stir contents of cup to fully integrate the coffee.
Chemex] Chemex is a design icon of the coffee world originally invented in 1941. The proprietary thick filter removes more oil and sediments from the coffee than any other brew method, leaving a smooth and acidic cup. Recommend using a gooseneck kettle for pouring water.
Place vessel either on top of coffee cup or on stand with cup/carafe below.
Crease the paper filter along the ridged edge, place the filter in the brewer and completely wet with hot water.
Grind the coffee on a V-60/paper filter setting, dump grounds in brewer, dump out hot water from cup/carafe.
Start timer and make initial pour of INT UNITS, take a spoon and stir the grounds to ensure that all grinds are wet. Let bloom.
At 45 seconds, slowly pour bringing the total amount of water to INT UNITS. When pouring, make small concentric circles in the center, ensuring to not touch the sides of the brewer. Pour should be 15 seconds finishing at 1:00.
At 1:30 begin third pour, bringing the total amount of water to INT UNITS, finishing at 1:45.
At 2:00 begin the last pour, bringing the toal amount of water to INT UNITS, finishing at 2:15.
Coffee should finish dripping around 2:30-3:15, remove brewer and stir contents of cup to fully integrate the coffee.
Cold Brew] Cold brew coffee makes for a strong, full-bodied, iced coffee beverage. There are many different vessles to make cold brew in, this method can be used interchangeably on any of them.
Grind coffee on french press setting.
Dump grounds into brewer.
Add INT UNITS cold tap water.
Stir ensuring to get all grounds wet.
At 16-18 hours, stir grounds one more time and filter out coffee into a large carafe.
Diltute with water. Recipe is generally 1:1 coffee:water, but it is recommended to add the water to best taste. Store in refrigerater. Good for 7-10 Days. Serve with Ice.
Kalita Wave] The Kalita Wave is can produce an awesome balanced and sweet cup of coffee. Its flat bottom causes an even extraction pulls out sweetness and body in the cup. This guide reccomends a coarse grind, and uses agitation to slow the brew time down.
Bring water to a boil.
Rinse paper filter, retaining natural filter shape.
Grind the coffee on coarse setting, dump grounds in brewer, dump out hot water from cup/carafe.
Start timer and make initial pour of INT UNITS, take a spoon and stir the grounds to ensure that all grinds are wet. Let bloom.
At 45 seconds, quickly pour in a circular pattern bringing the total amount of water to INT UNITS.
Continue adding pulses of INT UNITS of water at a time, making sure to keep water bed elevated.
Coffee should finish dripping around 3:45 with INT UNITS as its final weight. remove brewer and stir contents of cup to fully integrate the coffee.

About the recipe The recipes for all of these brew methods is based on a recipes that aim for a total dissolved solid (TDS) ratio of 1.38\-1.45. These recipes are great for a starting place but due to the variety in coffees and roasts, adjustments may be necessary. Recipe chart showing extraction profile
